name: How anxious am I?

cards.heading: Is this something to worry about?

dynamic_description.text: This test indicates that you have {{PARTA}} . About 54% of respondents who took this test fall in the same bracket. We recommend reading ahead to understand how you can maintain these levels more efficiently.

Our mind works ahead of us to protect us. So sometimes we fear what's going to happen in the future and we feel anxious. Your report suggests that you might be experiencing moderate to high levels of anxiety. The frequency of its occurance can affect different areas of your circle including {{PARTA}} . While anxiety is your protective response, it is important to learn how to regulate it. Be assured that you can learn tools that help you manage this.

data.substitute: work, relationships and the overall quality of life

cards.heading: Can you tell me where this is coming from?
pointers: Temperament stability
Uncontrolled worry
Lack of self control

cards.heading: Make a conscious effort to reduce this to improve your resilience
pointers: Difficulty in relaxing
What if thoughts
Constant future anxiety

cards.heading: Our expert psychologist wants you to know
cards.description: "You display an immense capacity to manage some of the big stressors. In your current state of mind, you could experience mood swings, also possible reactionary responses that may not be planned or intentioned."

cards.heading: Within this score range, you can notice the following behaviors
cards.description: While it differs from people to people, some common things to lookout for
pointers: A mix of cautious with adventure
A blend of outgoingness and occasional introversion
Migraines
Minor viral infections
Stress eating

report.heading: What are recommendations for your support system?

cards.heading: Relationship support that can help you thrive
cards.description: Healthy relationships play a pivotal role in life. Here's a few things you can say to those close to you:
cards.info: There are ways you can receive support from your closed ones:
pointers: Practice square breathing before a big communication
Ask HALT: Are you hungry, angry, lonely or tired?
Begin highly emotional statements with: I feel
Take water breaks during confrontational discussions
Give a heads up when you are stressed, tired or emotional
When sharing, first decide if you want ‘Comfort or Solution?’

cards.heading: Workplace accommodations that will help you thrive
cards.description: Share this at your workplace to help navigate relationships.
cards.info: Take a moment to go through and share with your team members and if necessary, with supervisors:
pointers: At a given point, focus on 2 major projects and 3 medium tasks
10- 10- 10 rule: Every 10 mins look at something 10 feel away for 10 secs
Schedule a mental health break every 1.5- 2 months
Plan check in meetings with manager, HR and in house therapists
Organise work with schedules, priority planners to reduce frenzy with last minute tasks

footer.heading: Take a screenshot and share this with your partner/manager/family

cards.heading: Not a Bookworm? Try This Movie Instead

cta.text: by Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris

report.description: Based on your score, here's how you can dive deeper into understanding and improving your emotional well-being:

cards.heading: Small Hack
cards.description: Small hack: We're not going to ask you to stop overthinking. But can we scheudle it? Schedule an overthinking hour in your day and when worries come up during the day, remind yourself that you'll sit with that thought in your hour.

dynamic_description.text: You can share this report with our expert psychologists {{THERAPIST_0}} and {{THERAPIST_1}} who specialise in working with your concerns.

report.heading: Closing Note
report.description:
Think of anxiety like a fire alarm. You want it to go off when there's a fire but not when you're baking cookies. Let's work with it and learn how to regulate.

With love,
MindPeers
